text: hi everyone bethany god tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new yard act
record the overload this is the debut
full-length lp of leeds rock outfit yard
act a post-punk band that has been just
speed running singles throughout much of
2020 and 2021 like this
what are you talking about because i'm
single
so a lot of these tracks landed on their
uh that dropped at the start of that
year met many more of the songs landed
on this record with some additional cuts
to fill out an 11 track 37 minute
experience giving us a pretty tight and
straightforward first impression of the
band track to track on this thing we are
getting a lot of driving and slightly
danceable grooves played out by thin
bass lines kind of rickety guitars which
are topped with endless strings of
spoken word vocals from front man james
smith for this genre of music that's
pretty much a winning formula based on
what's already worked for classic acts
such as wire or the fall who i think
yard act have quite a bit in common with
but obviously take a more measured
approach which is maybe driven by far
less days spent drinking and far more
days spent at the library also think
sleaford mods but with a full backing
band and way less pent up working class
rage some of the best moments on this lp
see the band pairing very simple sweet
straightforward hooks and melodies with
irresistible drum beats and a total
onslaught of social commentary
absurdities the overload for example
which is a fantastic intro track for
this record and sees the band pretty
much broadcast their mo not just
aesthetically but lyrically too the
overload of discontent the constant
burden of making sense it won't relent
it won't repent how to remain in
dissonance yeah that's pretty much what
the tense fusion of bass drums and
spoken word vocals on this record feels
like trying to navigate a senseless
world while also making something that
reflects it and
working as hard as you can to
make as little sense as possible be as
vigorously disjointed as possible the
first verse on this track showcasing a
very hopeless and bleak portrayal of
modern youth culture meanwhile the
second is some really hilarious
commentary on a band being told to
behave and it's kind of explained all
the ways they need to bend over
backwards in order to get popular and
get a gig later in the record land of
the blind has these really slow punchy
beats solid pick baseline and these kind
of lazy vocal harmonies that sound like
something from a gorilla's record like
the first one this serves as a very
solid chorus while eerie guitar
embellishments and some bleak social
commentary rings through on the verses
and mind you james smith isn't just
rambling on on this track and many
others too there are some great rhyme
schemes in the second half of this cut
for example the track poor another has a
very peppy keyboard backed hook maybe
the most blissful and genuinely feel
good moment on the entire lp there's
almost a new wave groove to it too which
tracks with the song's lyrics about
coming together and putting judgment
aside i think the closing track on this
lp is a strong note to end on too i have
to give it to the inspiring lyrics on
this cut about finding meaning in a
chaotic existence the whole thing sounds
like a heavenly decree coming down from
a post-punk angel now there are plenty
of other tracks on this lp where
i find them to have a very smart
on-point
witty grim even profound commentary but
those words aren't really cut with
enough
strong songwriting or melody or
variation dead horse for example does
have me on the edge of my seat listening
to all of this commentary about the uk's
culture dying on the vine people falling
for xenophobic lies or the collective
consciousness being poisoned by fake
news audiences being unwilling to try
anything new with a shot at sham 69 in
the lyrics mind you the oy scene is
shook mind you this point is being made
on a relatively regressive post-punk
album aesthetically anyway but the group
chanted chorus on this one is just a
mess and really meager feels very thrown
together meanwhile it doesn't really
bookend the verses all that well so
you know james smith's lyrics come off
kind of like a difficult swamp to wade
through with the song payday the hand
drums and grinding bass and also the
somewhat callous and irreverent
commentary on
poverty
comes off just a wee bit obnoxious while
i know these elements especially the
spoken word vocals are you know kind of
key characteristics of the strain of
post punk this track to me feels like
just too much of a good thing maybe
which is even more so the case for the
following track rich the groove and
pacing of this one are kind of tedious
but i do like the points that are being
made in regards to wealth accumulation
and greed uh yeah it's it's a point the
issue is is that point is just beaten
into the ground like a uh pile of dead
horses uh being whacked with the eiffel
tower quarantine the styx has some tense
passages that i like a lot the song
serves as a smart statement on
drawing lines and the ever-changing
sands of time the inevitability of
change but it still doesn't excuse the
vocal layering and singing on this track
being so subpar even for a record with
punk in its dna tall poppies is a pretty
interesting cut that i enjoy slightly
more in concept uh than in practice it
has a few moments that lull but i do
like the very thorough storyline being
presented on this track about an average
guy from a small village a footballer
with a dedicated practice schedule
eventually gets a job selling houses
settles down really telling the guy's
whole life story it eventually like
breaks quickly into a finishing scene
where he's like you know having a heart
attack and there's some final commentary
on his existence and life and how he's a
person you're a person we're all just
people there's even a sudden psa passage
about uh you know book an appointment
get checked out book an appointment
there is an odd shift into an apology
about
a western imperialism that feels kind of
out of place in this story and also uh
maybe just like you know a little too
flippantly thrown out there but it's
still a relative highlight on the lp
that shows the band is like you know
attempting something showing some kind
of ambition and that's kind of what this
lp boils down to for me there's a lot of
potential there the band is showcasing
some great tracks here and there in the
tracklist but there are some spots where
something feels missing or maybe they're
just a little too over the top or the
commentary being handed down in the
lyrics could use some focus and
sharpening so while i don't love this
thing i do think this is an impressive
start uh for yard act certainly i'm
feeling a strong six to a light seven on
